characters: DIED ON FEBRUARY 6TH 1952. HE WAS KNOWN AS 'THE GOOD KING
BERTIE. HIS STORY REMAINS UNKNOWN. EVEN IN AUSTRALIA.
THE COMMONWEALTH, REFUSING TO LEAVE LONDON DURING THE BLI
PRINCE OF WALES TELLS MINERS "SOMETHING MUST BE DONE
THE GLOWING DIAL OF A RADIO
INT/EXT. AUSTIN PRINCESS ON SOUTH KENSINGTON STREET
INT/EXT. AUSTIN PRINCESS, HYDE PARK CORNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shimmering surface of cold water - held in an immense, standing, white enamelled bathtub with gilded lion's legs bulges in SLOW MOTION to the chords of Handel's "Trumpet Volunteer". A head emerges. White gloved hands, in livery, rush to envelope the surfa naked wet body in white towels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ritual continues with crisp military precision. CLOSE ON the Royal Coat Of Arms stamped in gold: lion and unicorn embrace a shield divided into four quarters with thistle, and more lions denoting England, Ireland, Scotla Wales. The shield is surmounted by a crown. This emblem is on a cuff-link fastened on a starched whit shirt. Trousers, pressed to a knife-edge, are held for stockinge and gartered legs to be inserted. Mirror-polished boots are laced tight. Jacket, held ready. Arms, shoulders, chest received. Glistening medals attached to front of jacket create a da field of ribbons and medallions. Epaulets, edged with gold braid tassels, are adjusted. Polished buttons are fastened. Multi-coloured collar clasped shut. White ostrich feathers, topping a tri-corner hat, are flu and placed upon brilliantined hair. PAN DOWN to the handsome features of Albert, Duke of York to his family as BERTIE. He's in his late thirties, the s son of King George V, the reigning King of England. He co sensitivity which appears in conflict with the manner in he's been bedecked. Reflected in a full length mirror, Bertie tells himself: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                    3

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look like a Christmas tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles wanly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE ROYAL STANDARD flaps atop a gleaming chrome grill. Liveried footmen open the doors of a stately Austin Princ Bertie exits York House with his young wife - ELIZABETH - considered by all to be one of the loveliest women in the truly an English rose. Golden Labradors and Corgis appear all directions, weaving between them, barking boisterousl creating a happy chaos. Elizabeth and Bertie glance upwards and wave. Two little girls, LILIBET and MARGARET ROSE, aged eight a four, wave back from their nursery window.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. AUSTIN PRINCESS, HYDE PARK CORNER
dialogues.text: Bertie nervously lights a cigarette.    Elizabeth pats hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buck up, Bertie. The BBC said it wouldn't rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BERTIE'S POV - Speaker's Corner with its assortment of or prophets, protestors, and onlookers gathered around soapb agreeing, disagreeing, shouting comments. Others carry placards, sing protest songs. A miners' strike is the foc the day. A large, rather untidy workingman with a florid rosacea n spots the passing Austin and stares at the occupants. REVERSE ANGLE - Bertie's face stares back. The first drops splatter against the glass.      Elizabet

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never trust the wireless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie's face is obliterated by the increasingly heavy do which segues into a GARGLING sound. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gentleman in a tuxedo, carnation in boutonniere, is gar while a TECHNICIAN holds a porcelain bowl and a towel at ready. The man in the tuxedo is a BBC NEWS READER. He expectorates discreetly into the bowl, wipes his mouth fastidiously, and signals to ANOTHER TECHNICIAN who produ atomizer. The Reader opens his mouth, squeezes the rubber and sprays his inner throat. Now, he's ready. He looks to control room. The FLOOR MANAGER begins a count-down: five... four... th two...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and Gentlemen: good afternoon. This is the BBC National and World Programmes taking you to Wembley Stadium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He speaks in flawless pear-shaped tones.    There's no hi creature in the vocal world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELEVATED SHOT looking down on a sea of dripping black umb hiding the spectators from view. Bertie and Elizabeth takes their places in a row of gilde chairs with the other dignitaries. They are: KING GEORGE V - a barrel-chested man with Naval beard and uniform, accompanied by his wife. QUEEN MARY - an elegant but icy grande dame. DR COSMO LANG - a tall, unctuous, churchman with a high, balding head, and a perpetual expression of moral superio WINSTON CHURCHILL - a politician of sixty, as portly as L lean. They are bantering rivals in ambition. STANLEY BALDWIN - the Prime Minister of the day. Heavy-br His hair, as always, parted down the middle. NEVILLE CHAMBERLAIN - Chancellor of the Exchequer. Tall, lugubrious, with the expression of a quizzical chicken ha A BBC technician places a huge imposing microphone suspen springs next to the stadium equipment. It looks frighteni even to us. Bertie's shoulders brace as though expecting blow. Elizabeth sees his terror. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                  5.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why wasn't he told?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten million people listening around the world, Mam. Possibly more. (as though Bertie didn't exist) His brother, and father, have been broadcasting since last year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The King, growing impatient, hisses:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get on with it. Show what you're made of!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie moves forward diffidently, without an ounce of confidence, knowing deep within he's doomed. His stomach chest muscles contract, constricting his breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luh-luh-lords, la-la-ladies, gen-tell-men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a shock to realize this is a man with a profound st A man who cannot speak in public. Lang whispers to Churchill.    When Lang whispers, everyo hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't miss His Highness' maiden voyage for all the world. And on such an important occasion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lang really is a piece of work. For ease of reading, Bertie's stutter is not indicated fr point on in the script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No doubt you wish the Prince Of Wales was standing before you today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POV - a sea of dripping umbrellas. No response. This is g to be a torment for him, and his audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A glowing dial on the face of a studio radio.    Everyone listening intently. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                  6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stuttering profoundly) Be that as it may...my brother David is attending to other duties in the furthest parts of this vast Empire...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The radio falls silent.       Eyes widen in concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie stands frozen, his mouth agape, jaw muscles locked knows he's considered by all, especially himself, unfit f public life. Elizabeth is devastated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just needs more practice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRACKING SHOT - rain splatters on brass plaques denoting or Dr That, specialists in various maladies. Halt at a pl that reads: LIONEL LOGUE, SPEECH SPECIALIST.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Umbrella stand, coat rack, wooden waiting bench: that's a The door is flung open and Elizabeth enters, drenched, he decorated with white silk roses, now limp. A veil covers features. She waits. Coughs.    No response.    Calls imperiously:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From behind a door:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the lav.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Princess Elizabeth is not used to this sort of thing. She further appalled by the loud gurgling of a toilet being f and startled by the entrance of - LIONEL LOGUE. He's in h forties, tall, with piercing eyes and charismatic feature demeanor is friendly, but professional. The accent, altho Australian, is not heavy, he is after all a speech therap TKS/Seidler/09/17/08 LIONEL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "How poor are they that have not patience! What wound did ever heal but by degrees?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon? LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iago...world's greatest villain. Just wants to be bad. Sorry, no receptionist. He offers to shake hands.    She doesn't take it, even th she's gloved. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with sang froid) I'd be more comfortable in your office. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's for clients. Where's Mister J? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't know I'm here. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not a promising start. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My husband's seen everyone. They were all useless. He's given up hope. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bit premature. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he hasn't seen you? Lionel doesn't disgree. ELIZABETH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're very sure of yourself. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure of anyone who wants to be cured. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course my husband wants to be cured! His position requires public speaking upon occasion. A torment. I fear the requirement may grow more frequent. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He should change jobs. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indentured servitude? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something of that nature. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, have your `hubby' pop by and give his personal history. I'll make a frank appraisal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor... Logue tries to object but she over-rides. ELIZABETH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I do not have a "hubby". We never talk about our private lives. Nor do we `pop'. You must come to us. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, this is my game, played on my turf, by my rules. The lady lifts her veil. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps you'll make an exception? He recognizes her instantly, and is clearly impressed, ye refuses to be intimidated. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought the appointment was for "Johnson"? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A name used during the Great War, when the Navy didn't wish the enemy to know His Royal Highness was aboard. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm considered the enemy? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will be, should you continue to be un- obliging. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                  9.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For my method to succeed there must be mutual trust, complete honesty, and total equality. That process takes place in my consultation room. No exceptions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In which case... (re-lowering her veil) I should have kept my pledge. I promised my husband I'd stop seeking "The Great Cure." I've wasted your time. And mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She exits, closing the door firmly behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloody hell, I buggered that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WACK! The sound of something solid meeting leather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A foot kicks a ball. Lionel is returning home from work. well-known fixture locally. Some lads are playing footie. of them passes the ball to Lionel who, despite briefcase rolled brolly, dribbles skillfully before passing the bal entering a modest brownstone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Lionel mounts the stairs he's set upon by three sturdy VALENTINE, IAN, and PETER - with handkerchiefs tied aroun lower portions of their faces and armed with broomstick s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand and deliver!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (falling into the game) `ow dares molest...Jack The Ripper?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys scream with delight and a sword fight ensues - L using his brolly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beware, Highwaymen, or I'll run yee through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're Swagmen, not Highwaymen, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   10

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. (then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beware, jolly Swagmen, I'll skewer yer gizzards. Lionel wife - MYRTLE - appears at the head of the stairs; sweet-faced, down-to-earth woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll all hang from the gallows if you don't come for tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boys, I think we'd best go up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Logue, Myrtle, and the boys are finishing at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had a visit from a lady today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another spoiled silly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May we be excused?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must stay, bored stupid, listening to your parents' inane conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, dad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And mum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And mum! They start to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your plates. The boys grabs their plates and exit. After a moment...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No wonder about the silly. You're so good at what you do. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At what I do. (then, deliberately being `theatrical') Twas a Lady with a capital L.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Lionel, that'd get us home in grand style wouldn't it?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She came on behalf of her husband. Which is not the proper way. I told her I was fully booked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myrtle is clearly disappointed

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was...too high and mighty. Know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She does.   There's an unspoken code between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We wouldn't want that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Covers her letdown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard to feel sorry for that sort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had a call. Wish me luck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Course, Lionel. Loads and loads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth, fashionably attired for an evening-out, is cur a bearskin rug reading "Peter Pan" to the girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Mr. and Mrs. Darling and Nana rushed into the nursery too late. The birds were flown."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie enters, handsome in a tuxedo.     Elizabeth closes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow, Chapter IV, `The Flight'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                    1 The two little girls clap with joy. MARGARET ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, to fly away! BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weren't they lucky. Within his family, Bertie's stutter is virtually absent. LILIBET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One would have to learn to fly properly of course. MARGARET ROSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now a Daddy story! BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I be a penguin instead? He drops to his knees and waddles. In his tux he looks li penguin. The girls giggle, but are undeterred. LILIBET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The horsie story, please. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah well. Called upon to perform, the stutter returns slightly. But two girls listen raptly, ignoring their father's minor impediment, and it fades. BERTIE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once upon a time there were two horsies. A white horse that went clip clop clip clop through Hyde Park. And a black horse that went clip clop clip clop through Hyde Park. They met in the middle of Hyde Park. The white horse said "neigh". The black horse said, "neigh". The white horse continued on, clip clop clip clop through Hyde Park. The black horse continued on, clip clop clip clop through Hyde Park. And that's the end of the story. Now off to bed. As the girls exit: LILIBET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A silly story really. But Father tells it rather well. The girls have gone. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                               13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David called. He said come round to The Fort on Friday and stay for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will she be there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously, she'll be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I meant... is David serious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About our coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A married American? Twice divorced? He can't be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Movements behind a curtain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now? From the auditorium:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now! Someone pushes through a gap. Its Lionel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Now..." Falters, begins again. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                    1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Now is the winter of our discontent Made glorious summer by this sun of York..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His elocution is crisp and flawless. His acting, however, unconvincing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "And all the clouds that lour'd upon our house In the deep bosom of the ocean buried. Now are our brows bound with victorious wreaths..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupts crisply) Thank you. Beautiful diction...but I don't hear the cries of a deformed creature yearning to be King.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel struggles to maintain a semblance of dignity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you suggest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continue to do whatever you do, and hope it gives you a great deal of satisfaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crushed, Lionel retreats behind the curtain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cold and austere mausoleum illuminated by floodlights. On the parade ground, Grenadier Guards in red coats and b bearskin busbies drill stiffly like toy soldiers. Viewing are beginning to fill. The King's voice is heard:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stride boldly up to the bloody thing, stare it square in the eye, and talk to it as you would to any decent Englishman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The King's study resembles a naval captain's cabin. Both are uniformed for a state occasion. Bertie regards the BB microphone as though it were an alien. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                    1 BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I d-d-don't thu-thu-think I c-c-can. In the presence of his father, Bertie's stuttering return full form, his breathing short and shallow, the muscles i spasms. KING GEORGE V

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show who's in command. If you don't, this devilish device will change everything. Used to be, all a King had to do was look reasonable in uniform and not fall off his horse. Now we must creep cap in hand into people's homes that smell of boiled cabbage, and speak nicely to them. We're reduced to that lowest, basest of all creatures...we've become...actors! Don't give me a look of defeated pathos. This is a family crisis! BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father, we're not a family, we're a firm. His father shoots Bertie a surprised look.   Does the lad brain after all? KING GEORGE V

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're the oldest, most successful, corporation in the world and sitting on thrones is our business! But any moment now we may be out of work. Your brother came to me the other day, livid a certain lady has been refused an invitation to my Silver Jubilee. I pointed out she wasn't a lady and most definitely wasn't his wife. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did David say? KING GEORGE V

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She made him sublimely happy. I said: that was probably because she was sleeping with him. "I give you my word we've never had immoral relations." "As my son, as Prince of Wales, as my heir, do you solemnly swear your friendship with this woman is an absolutely clean one?" "I do", he said. "Look me in the eye," I said. "On my honour" he said. Stared straight at his father... and lied. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my brother... TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                    1 KING GEORGE V

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I'm dead that boy will ruin himself, this family, and this nation, within twelve months. Who'll pick up the pieces? David's friend, Oswald Mosley? His black-shirt British Union of Fascists are marching through London. Hitler terrorizing half of Europe, Stalin the other half. Who'll stand between us, the jackboots, and the proletarian abyss? You? A red light attached to the mike begins a series of warni blinks. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you going to say? KING GEORGE V

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The usual guff. The Archbishop writes it. My people love to hear me say it. Spoken fluently, of course. They're interrupted by the entrance of the BBC News Reade Technicians. KING GEORGE V (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the chap who taught me how to use this contraption. You touch your chin with your thumb and the `thing' with the end of your little finger. Splendid fellow. SQUISH.   Assisted by the Technicians, the News Reader sp throat. BBC NEWS READER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, ladies and gentlemen, this is the BBC, broadcasting direct from Buckingham Palace upon the occasion of the Royal Silver Jubilee. His Majesty: King George the Fifth. KING GEORGE V

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the mike) "I can only say to you, my very very dear people, that the Queen and I thank you from the depths of our hearts for all the loyalty and - may I say so? - the love with which this day and always you have surrounded us. I dedicate myself anew to your service for all the years that may still be given to me." The News Reader, terribly moved, whispers to his Technici TKS/Seidler/09/17/08

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's how a King speaks. (adds with splendid false modesty) I showed HM how to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The edge of the crowd is visible. One can sense a vast se humanity. When the glass doors of the upper balcony open murmur becomes a ROAR. When the King steps out, it become tumultuous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The King is joined by Queen Mary and the Archbishop of Canterbury, other Royals, and dignitaries. The noise is deafening. The King beckons impatiently for someone still inside to join them. It's Bertie, with Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They didn't come to see us, Father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's David?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bedding his American whore. Come, join the fun! (aside to Elizabeth) You'll have to do a lot more of this. I'm sending him to the Midlands. With all the factory noise they won't hear a word he says.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The King goes back to waving.   Elizabeth is stunned at t prospect. The ROAR of the crowd segues into the ROAR of machinery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huge industrial wheels whir in neutral. WORKERS are lined dutifully to hear the visiting Royal. Bertie's lips move, with the noise he cannot be heard. Elizabeth watches in r Then a FOREMAN, trying to be helpful, signals.     The ma halts, the factory falls silent. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08 At first the momentum of speaking without being heard car Bertie forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's needed is cooperation...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hearing his own voice reverberate through the cavernous f brings Bertie's stutter back in full form.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...buh-buh-between the cuh-cuh-classses...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the workers sullenly pulls a chain, releasing a bl from a steam whistle that drowns Bertie out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE ROYAL STANDARD fluttering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth and Bertie in the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this necessary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know perfectly well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they pass a corner news stand, the headline chalkboard

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neglects to tell them what must be done, how its to be done, and who's to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David has `the touch'. They adore him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Austin halts for lights, people stare to see who's inside. Some point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll wager they're saying: There's the useless one who can't speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie and Elizabeth enter. She explains in a whisper: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   19 ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no receptionist. Elizabeth glances nervously at the lavatory door. ELIZABETH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loudly) The Johnsons. From the inner office. LIONEL (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not finished yet. Elizabeth is relieved its not coming from the lav. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you find this physician? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (poker-faced) Classifieds; next to "Saucy model, Shepherd's Market". Bertie smiles despite his mood. ELIZABETH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Comes highly recommended. Charges substantial fees in order to help the poor. (realizes) Oh dear, perhaps he's a Bolshevik?! BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I want to see this fellow. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure he wants to see you. The consultation room door opens and a working class youn - ANNA - comes out; then realizes with a gasp who they ar retreats rapidly back into the consulting room. ELIZABETH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps this was a mistake. After an uncomfortable moment, Anna returns, attempting t properly formal, and stutters: ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can go in now, "Mr. Johnson". BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not actually Mr ... TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   20

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers, terrified)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. (then to Elizabeth)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr Logue says...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel says...wait here if you wish. Or, it being a pleasant day, take a stroll. (to the consultation room)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was that alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloody marvellous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (choking up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you...Lionel. Anna flees quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Johnson, do come in. The Yorks look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A totally different universe from the Spartan waiting are world of books - piles of them spilling everywhere. Two slightly shabby, but comfortable armchairs. Well-worn Tur rug. Hotplate and two chipped mugs. Model airplanes hangi from the ceiling. Recording apparatus. The walls are pear and smoky blue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife's favorite colours. Here, in a doctor's office, Bertie's stutter returns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glad we have something in common. Bertie's head bangs into one of the models.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lads build them. Make yourself comfortable. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                    2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're too close. Five paces is the rule of thumb. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That might be difficult in this office. Bertie perches uneasily on the edge of an armchair. LIONEL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice girl, Anna. Worried she wouldn't find a husband if she couldn't speak. Tried to convince her men will find her even more attractive as a silent partner. The perfect woman. Sorry, bad Australian joke. Why'd your wife change her mind and ask for an appointment? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't discuss that. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can we talk about? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's better. When speaking with a Royal one waits for the Royal to start the conversation and chose the topic. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your joking. That won't work here. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I admit if one waits for me to start a conversation one can wait a rather long time. Silence.   They stare at each other. BERTIE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You call this making me comfortable? LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You call this being forthcoming? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you interested in treating me? TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   22 LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only if you're interested in being cured. More silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cuppa tea? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thank you. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need one. Turns on the hot plate. LIONEL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any idea what you're letting yourself in for? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apparently a great deal of rudeness, Doctor Logue. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me Lionel. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I prefer Doctor. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I prefer Lionel. My family calls me far worse. What shall I call you? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Duke of York is appropriate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh please. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Royal Highness then. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much more informal. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prince Albert? Or Frederick? Arthur? George? I've lots of names to choose from. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about Bertie? TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   23 BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flushes) Only my family uses that. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I'll call you then. We must be true equals. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we were equal I wouldn't be here, I'd be at home with my family and no-one would give a damn. Bertie starts to light a cigarette from a silver case. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do that. Bertie gives him an astonished look. LIONEL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sucking smoke into your lungs will kill you. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My physicians say it's good for stuttering, relaxes the throat. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're idiots. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've all been knighted. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Makes it official then. House rules: no smoking. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought here we're "equal". LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a monarchist I thought you'd appreciate these are my digs and here I rule. No smoking. What was your earliest memory? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon? LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First recollection of the world? TKS/Seidler/09/17/08 BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stutter growing in intensity) I'm not here to discuss personal matters. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why're you here then? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exploding) Because I bloody well stutter! And you bloody well can't fix it!!! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Temper. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of my numerous faults. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you stutter when you think? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be ridiculous. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of my many faults. How about when you talk to yourself? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't talk to myself! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, everyone natters to themselves once in a while, Bertie. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop calling me that! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shan't call you anything else. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we shan't speak! Silence. The jug has boiled.    Lionel makes himself a cu BERTIE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must I pay for this? LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loads. Now: when you talk to yourself, do you stutter? TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   25 BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Proving your impediment isn't a permanent internal fixture. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I give a speech...I bloody stutter!!! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bet you a bob you can read flawlessly, right here, right now. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) Easy money. You're on. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See your shilling then. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Royals don't carry money. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How convenient. Logue fishes a coin from his pocket and puts it on the ta LIONEL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll stake you. Pay me back next time. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there is a next time. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Correct, I haven't agreed to take you on. During this, Logue has uncovered a piece of apparatus, a recording device with earphones. He sets a blank disc ont turntable and positions a microphone, then hands Bertie a book. Bertie glares at it defiantly. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I certainly can't read The Bard. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `Easy money'. Bertie reads, stuttering badly and getting worse. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "To be or not to be, That is the question. Whether it is wiser..." There! TKS/Seidler/09/17/08 Reaches for the coin. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not so fast. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I proved I can't read. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You proved you can't listen. Hands Bertie a pair of heavily padded earphones.    Berti want to take them. LIONEL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A princely bob is at stake. Bertie reluctantly puts on the earphones. Logue turns a d LOUD MUSIC is heard. Bertie takes off the earphones. The stops. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're playing music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm aware. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can I hear what I'm saying?! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie, you're Royal. Surely a prince's brain knows what its mouth is doing? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not well acquainted with Royal princes, are you? LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to demonstrate that when you can't hear your voice, you don't stutter, thus proving your impediment is not innate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rubbish. Bertie replaces the earphones. Again, the LOUD MUSIC. His move as he reads, but all that can be heard is the music. Finished reading the passage he takes off the earphones a music ceases. He reaches for the coin, but Logue snatches BERTIE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was terrible. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   27

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flawless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know how I sound!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would I lie to a prince of the realm to win twelve-pence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've no idea what an Australian might do for that sort of money. Logue puts the record in a brown paper dust jacket and ha to Bertie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Souvenir of our first and presumably last encounter. Bertie glances at the record. POV - the label: HMV His Master's Voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth, trying to be gracious, has been cooling her he with a working class MOTHER and her young son WILLIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm finished with your husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm finished with Doctor Logue!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel. They exit curtly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was that...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly not. How's it going, mate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William isn't trying hard enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie? TKS/Seidler/09/17/08

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ddddddoooing ggggggggood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why am I not surprised?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Yorks are being driven home. As they pass Speakers' C Oswald Mosley's blackshirt British Union of Fascists are full force.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bloody man did parlour tricks and cheated me out of a shilling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In fury he rolls down the window and is about to throw aw record. Elizabeth stops him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He quickly rolls up the window. The sound of an approaching aircraft engine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A grass strip cut into the moors. Bertie waits beside a s break, the stiff breeze whipping his coat, as a small pla lands and taxis. The cockpit canopy slides back and the p leaps out, removing his leather helmet and goggles, revea hair gleaming like gold, perfect teeth flashing a dentist smile. This is - DAVID - the Prince of Wales, Prince Char the media's darling, a sun god descended from the skies accustomed to being worshipped by all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (teasing with a false stutter) Hello, B-b-bertie. B-b-been waiting long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three days. Where've you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie stutters badly in the presence of his brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So was I. Elizabeth has pneumonia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll recover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie shoots him a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David drives.   Badly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's doing this on purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dying?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some sod tipped him off Wallis is getting a quickie divorce and we're going to make our marriage a fait accompli. As an act of pure spite, Father's trying to depart prematurely in order to complicate matters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The break almost careens off the lane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You believe that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallis explained it. She's terribly clever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The King is propped up in bed, wrapped in his favorite fa Tibetan dressing gown, hooked to an oxygen tank. He's surrounded by his wife, Queen Mary, his two eldest sons, Secretary - CLIVE WIGRAM - his personal physician - DR DA and a NURSE. Wigram presents a tray with papers and pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Instruments Of Succession, Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The King is so feeble he can barely make his mark. Glares David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're next? God help us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08 He waves them out of the room, but beckons Wigram to come and whispers something in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the appropriate moment, Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The King nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clear soup is being served at the immense table.    Place five, but only Bertie and his mother are seated.    The c of silver and china. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want my jewelry divided equally. Elizabeth gets first choice. She's not greedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I remind you, you're not the one who's dying, Mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are the others?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord Wigram and Dr Dawson are making arrangements.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What sort of arrangements?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They didn't say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And David? Fetch him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, hunched over a table, appears to be sobbing.     H hear Bertie's discreet knock. Seeing his brother crying, Bertie is deeply moved, puts a comforting hand on his shoulder. David pulls away as thou touched by a leper and covers the receiver in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on with Wallis! (as though Bertie didn't exist)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                    3

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, darling, a talk, even a lovely long talk, is a poor substitute for holding tight and making drowsy. Nor making our own drowsies either, as we've had to do far too often lately. (kisses the phone) Til then, sweet love. (hangs up) Wally misses me terribly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother says you're late for supper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David glares at a clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clocks set five minutes in advance, so as not to be late. When I'm King I shall set them back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie and David enter to find Wigram and Dawson with the mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord Wigram has requested permission to order the coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody wants to take responsibility. The Queen looks to D He nods. They're interrupted by a BUTLER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Archbishop of Canterbury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the hell invited him?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody. Don't swear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody should bloody well dis-invite him. Father swears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be rash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not your father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                    3

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His Grace can be a persistent enemy. We need friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David knows he's referring to the Simpson affair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show the toad in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lang is already sweeping towards them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever can I contribute in this dreadful hour?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men are huddled, with cigars and port, composing a ne release. Bertie acts as secretary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Tranquilly"? "Serenely"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peacefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The King's life is moving peacefully to its..." "Termination"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...to its close."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a man of letters you're heaven-sent to assist in the editing of our press communique.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lang beams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll telephone this through to the BBC and alert The Times to hold the morning edition. The problem is...if we're to keep to schedule...time is running out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clock is approaching midnight. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                    3

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is my father late for death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We wouldn't want the news delivered by the disreputable afternoon press, would we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brothers look at him. He expains:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who knows what sensational side issues those tabloids might report.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps a peaceful termination?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All eyes on David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nurse looks aghast as Dr Dawson administers an inject

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three quarters of a gram of morphia and a gram of cocaine injected into the distended jugular vein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! that's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She does so, sobbing. Everyone watches silently as the King's breathing slows, twitching jugular subsides, then all movement ceases. Dawson takes the pulse, and consults his watch. David sets the hand of the room's big clock back by five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time of expiration, 11:55 pm. On schedule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Queen Mary curtsies in homage to the new King, taking her son's hand and kissing it. When she looks up...her eyes a chilling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long live the King.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                    3

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie, in despair and grief, has been describing to Eliz what happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The look in mother's eyes, it was...ghastly. He notices something on his desk, the record Logue made. POV: the label - His Master's Voice - stares up at him. He releases his emotions in an outburst of anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this bloody thing doing here?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man was a total fraud! He picks up the record and is about to smash it against t of his desk, then realizes the mess that would make and t it into a waste paper basket. Then changes his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to hear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not particularly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well   I think you should. You should know what   goes on. Telling me he could help me read   flawlessly. Lying bastard! Listen to this   babble! Bertie takes the record from the trash and walks to a Vic stand, lifts the arm, places the steel needle, expecting his stuttering voice. Instead, what he hears is flawless flowing:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "To be, or not to be, - that is the question: - Whether `tis nobler in the mind to suffer The slings and arrows of outrageous fortune, Or to take arms against a sea of troubles, And by opposing end them?" (the needle sticks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...sea of troubles, and by opposing end them? And by opposing end them? And by opposing..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie lifts the needle. He and his wife stare at each ot there are tears in her eyes. The ROAR OF A HUGE delirious crowd is heard, growing in v The roar becomes chillingly recognizable: "Zeig Heil! Zei Zeig Heil!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitler, giving one of his mass rally speeches, continues. The brass numbers 10 appears on the blackness.   It is:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The black front door of the Prime Minister's residence. T Fuhrer's tirade continues as CAMERA moves through the doo 10 Downing Street itself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA explores the dwelling, during which Hitler grows l and more shrill, until:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The glowing light of an illuminated dial of a radio, list by Churchill and Baldwin. They wear black armbands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn that devil off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hysteria stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If only one could do that so easily in real life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chamberlain thinks that Hitler can be reasoned with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neville is an old woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   36

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the direction its going, Winston. You're out of step.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll see who trips and falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough pleasantries. I've asked you here because you seem to be the only sensible member of the King's camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice of you to say so, Stanley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he willing to be reasonable?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Depends on the definition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bluntly) Has he seen the light?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baldwin brightens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our Monarch basks in the warming rays of a celestial orb. Her name is Wally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baldwin's face clouds once again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A headline screams: HITLER RATTLES SABRE. Lionel is at his desk reading the newspaper as his sons s on the floor building a model airplane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time for a Shake, dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleased) You sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shake! Shake! Shake!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clearly this is a much loved ritual. Lionel disappears in closet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bet its the Scottish Play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Othello!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps something with Falstaff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ominous thumps within the closet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Art thou afeard?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caliban!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel lumbers out of the closet, a pillow stuffed into h jacket to create a monstrous hunchback. His acting, perfo just for his children, is quite magical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Be not afeard; the isle is full of noises, Sounds and sweet airs, that give delight, and hurt not. Sometimes a thousand twanging instruments Will hum about mine ears; and sometimes voices, That, if then I had waked after long sleep, Will make me sleep again: and then, in dreaming, The clouds methought would open, and show riches Ready to drop upon me; that, when I waked, I cried to dream again."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lads are enthralled. The DOOR BELL RINGS. Lionel is n expecting anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Austin Princess waits at the curb.    Bertie is at th He rings the BELL again. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   38

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor Logue?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel is stunned, covers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must be a tradesman. Off you go, lads. Mum should be home from work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys gather their things, deposit the model plane on chair, stow the building materials in a box, and exit the way. Lionel goes to the door, but doesn't open it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Logue...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Logue, expressionless, doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie is torn: part of him wants to flee, yet he despera needs to be let in. He knows what must be done. This is a step for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel...it's Bertie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My condolences. I didn't expect you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. I didn't expect to be here. May I come in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife doesn't think it's a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myrtle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myrtle? Myrtle's never met me. I've never met Myrtle. May we discuss Myrtle in private? Its not proper talking about our women on the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonel gives him a look, but lets him him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they enter Bertie notices:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to your shoulder?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel hastily removes the pillow, tosses it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sore back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your Myrtle got to do with me? Elizabeth doesn't much care for you either, but here I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That woman has style.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is why she dislikes you. You're far too familiar. (referring to the consultation room) May we discuss this properly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look dreadful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another example of exactly the sort of thing you don't say to a Royal. And you're too close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're not Royal in this room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                    4 BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is precisely why Elizabeth dislikes you. He starts to sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not there! CRUNCH.   A model airplane was nestling in the armchair. LIONEL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis bi-plane, now a Curtis mono-wing. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh I say, I'm terribly sorry. Tell your lads I'll buy a new one. Lionel takes out the box of model building gear the boys LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have any money. I'll fix it. So, Bertie, what brings you here? Your father's death? Bertie is silent. LIONEL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mine lay rigid, fists clenched angrily at his sides, daring the Reaper: take me, you bastard! BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was he angry about? LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was a great disappointment. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought he'd be proud of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So did I. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man of stature?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A clerk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   41 BERTIE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was informed, after the fact, my father's last words were: "Bertie has more guts than the rest of his brothers put together." (pause) Couldn't say that to my face. (then) Your mother? LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coughed herself to death when I was young.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember going to the theatre with her. Not real theatre...traveling players. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been to Australia. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not where I lived. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blurts) My brother. That's why I'm here. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't say. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going home now. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must undersand, I can't puh-puh-puh... His jaw and throat muscles constrict. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try singing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon? LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know any songs? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Swanee River". TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                  42. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very modern. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happens to be my favorite. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sing it. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly not. (fascinated by the plane repairs) May I help? Always wanted to build models. Father wouldn't allow it. I had to collect stamps. He collected stamps. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only if you sing. Goes like this... (sings) "Way down upon the..." BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know the words! (sings) "Way down upon the Swanee River. ..." Etcetera. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't stutter. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I didn't stutter, I was singing! One doesn't stutter when one sings! (realises) ) Oh... (then) Well I can't waltz around on State occasions warbling! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can with me. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's because you're peculiar. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I take that as a compliment. Cut some struts from the balsa. Sorry, hard to show you what to do at five paces. Would you like a cup of tea? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Yes. Thank you. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                    4 Lionel fires up the hot plate. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were about to sing an aria concerning your brother. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not crooning to the tune of "Swanee River!" LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try "Camptown Races" then. (sings) "The Arch of C, he said to me, doo-dah doo- dah..." That sort of thing. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't talk, or sing, about your future King, doo-dah, doo-dah... LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My future King? He's your future King too. Did that cause friction? Knowing he'd grow up to be King, but you wouldn't. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly not. I've always looked up to David. Water's boiling. Lionel makes the pot. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two lumps or one? Bertie, a bit abashed, holds up three fingers. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've a sweet tooth. To tell the truth... LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Always preferable. (referring to plane wing) Cover it with tissue. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...it was a relief. Knowing I wouldn't be King. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why's that? Lionel hands him a mug of tea.   Bertie realizes it's chi possibly none too clean. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   44 BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't have to give speeches! Reaches into his jacket for his cigarette case. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No smoking. What's the age difference? While Logue isn't looking, Bertie surreptitiously wipes t of the mug with his handkerchief. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eighteen months. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But for eighteen months you would've been King?! BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We didn't think about it that way, doctor. (sings) Doo-dah doo-dah. (then) David and I were very close. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you said: eighteen months. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As brothers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How close? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young bucks... You know. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't, or I wouldn't ask. Did you go after the same girls? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upon occasion. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Princess Elizabeth? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flares) What an extraordinarily rude thing to say! (quickly under control) David did try to be her beau at one point. Before I met her. She wouldn't have him. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   45 BERTIE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not like my father...he and his brother, when they were young, kept a girl in St John's Wood and shared her on alternate nights. An uncomfortable silence.   Too much has been said. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now dope the other wing. Did David tease you? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all did. "Buh-buh-buh-Bertie". Father encouraged it. "Spit it out, boy!" Thought it would make me stop. Is this necessary?! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otherwise the paint will eat through the tissue. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean the damn questions! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandatory. Tell me more about your storybook childhood. What was your earliest memory? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You asked that before. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This time I'd like an answer. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Being born. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you remember that? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: December 14th. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Mausoleum Day". Prince Albert departed on that date. I was named Bertie to placate Great Grandmamma Victoria. In return, she hated me because it reminded her of her grief. (stutter growing in intensity) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   46 BERTIE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's stick to medical history please. I'm naturally left handed, which was considered inappropriate. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was punished. Now I'm right handed. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything else? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bandy legs. Also considered inappropriate. Lionel waits. BERTIE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Metal splints were made...worn night and day...very painful. Now I have straight legs. This is so...tawdry! I need your services as a Speech Therapist, not Grand Inquisitor. Are you available? Or will it be: "Myrtle says no?" LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sound angry. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I told you, I have a temper. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angry at me, or at your brother? Bertie remains stubbornly silent.    Then blurts: BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's fallen in love! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How dreadful. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the wrong sort of woman! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with her? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's American. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of them must be lovable. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   47 BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This one's divorced. Twice. Mrs Wallis Simpson of Baltimore. I want David to be happy, but the family, the Church, the nation, won't have it. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't they fornicate privately like adults? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If only! David used to prefer married women because there was no possible attachment. But now... LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Queen Wallis of Baltimore"? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does sound a bit iffy. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made a smudge! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Touch it up. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to beg for help? LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I advise you never to beg. Especially if you might be King. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't say that! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. For reasons you cannot disclose, fearing ramifications you will not explain, you feel sufficiently anxious to embark upon a course of therapy in which you have no faith? You already owe me a shilling. Bertie takes a coin out of his pocket, hesitates, then of to Logue. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I brought it along. You won, fair and square. I'll pay you generously. Lionel pockets the coin. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   48 LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll continue to ask questions. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I was afraid of. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (admires the plane) Nice job. Bertie sees Lionel glance at his watch. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've someone waiting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do now. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd apologize to them in person, but... LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't wish to be seen? Slip out the back way. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After the funeral...it may be even more difficult. To remain unobserved. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're having second thoughts. Bertie's silence is confirmation. LIONEL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ask too many questions? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps the wrong sort. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (writes an address) We live in South Kensington, small apartment, but no one would see you. (added incentive) Lots of planes. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Lionel, you're the first ordinary Englishman... LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Australian. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I've ever really talked to. Sometimes, when I ride through the streets and see a `bloke' I'm struck by how little I know of his life, and how little he knows of mine. Cuts both ways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Bertie is about to leave, Lionel requests casually:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if you decide to come, bring the Duchess. She might be helpful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She might. If I asked. Very nicely. (at back door) And how will Myrtle take to our coming into your home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not sure. She isn't speaking to me. (pause) Wants to go home. (pause) After the funeral then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie doesn't answer. Exits. Logue is left holding the p He goes to the waiting room door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How're you doing, Willie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speaking for her son) Still can't say a sentence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iiiiiii'm much bbbbbbbetter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A drum roll is heard.      Thrum.   Another...   Thrum! T

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funereal bagpipes wail, joining the measured drum-rolls. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08 On the balcony of the Castle, decorated with black buntin huge BBC microphone, and arrayed in front of it a row of uniformed dignitaries wearing Naval hats of the Napoleoni replete with ostrich feathers. One of the dignitaries reads a declaration: DIGNITARY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whereas it has pleased Almighty God to call to His mercy our late Sovereign, King George the Fifth of blessed and glorious memory... During this, INTERCUT to the REVERSE ANGLE, showing a mas military parade, mainly Navy personnel, wending its way t the main street of Windsor towards the Castle, accompanyi gun carriage on which rides the King's coffin, draped wit Royal standard, on which rests the Royal Crown topped by Maltese Cross. David is seen - very serious. DIGNITARY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...that the High and Mighty Prince Edward Albert Christian George Andrew Patrick David is now become our only lawful King. Canons are fired. Startled by the salute, a large flock of blackbirds rise streak across the wintery sky. A MURMUR, then a shocked GASP, as the gun carriage transv tram track and tilts precipitously. Suddenly the Royal Cr tumbles and falls, knocking off the Maltese Cross. COSMO LANG (O.C.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh bloody Hell! WINSTON CHURCHILL (O.C.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bad omen, Your Grace? The Archbishop and Churchill are watching the events from shadows at one end of the balcony. Below - a scramble to restore the Cross to the Crown, and replace both atop the coffin. COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be disingenuous. For our late King's crown to fall from his coffin is not a fortuitous portent. What ever is going to happen next? TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   51 WINSTON CHURCHILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that be the motto of the new reign? Indeed, will there actually be "a new reign"? COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winston! I'm deeply shocked. WINSTON CHURCHILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't look it. COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My function requires me to appear serene. WINSTON CHURCHILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That may be increasingly difficult to maintain. I've been informed by no less an authority than the Prime Minister that our populace has no objection to Royal fornication, but will never tolerate adultery. COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, since we cannot acquire a new populace, perhaps we need a new King? WINSTON CHURCHILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My turn to be profoundly shocked. Neither look the slightest traumatized. COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scoff, Churchill! Go on... scoff! But you more than others know full well we'll soon be under siege from the forces of darkness. WINSTON CHURCHILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The winds of war...a gathering storm? COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you do have a way with words. And who would you suggest to rally the troops, the nation, the Empire, the world? INTERCUT to Bertie in the funeral cortege, looking frail pale. COSMO LANG (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man who cannot speak? In Nuremberg stadium, Herr Hitler mesmerizes millions, whilst the Duke of York cannot successfully order fish and chips. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you prefer the next brother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT to Henry, the Duke of Gloucester.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bi-sexual former drug addict? The unwashed moralistic populace will adore that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The youngest, perhaps?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT to George, the Duke of Kent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now there's dimness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must admit...unburdened with brain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thus we're left with David, the rightful heir, who speaks beautifully, even if he talks nonsense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Below, the coffin is entering the Chapel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, let us bury one king, before we attempt to bring another to his knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Re-establishing shot.   The Royal standard flies bravely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie waits at a table with a group of immaculately atti courtiers and dignitaries. This is the Coronation Committ The chair at the head of the table is empty, everyone wai for its occupant. He finally arrives. David. He gestures for Bertie to come the corridor, but deliberately leaves the door open so th committee can hear snatches of Bertie's ensuing humiliati TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   53

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David has a habit of constantly fingering his tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear you're taking elocution lessons, lad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diction. Speechifying. That's the word around Town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merely trying to overcome my dreadful impediment...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the brother who speaks. Or do you wish to have a go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good lord no! I hope to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Replace me? Well...today's your chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He thrusts a document into Bertie's hands, then pokes his into the conference room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My brother will read the Coronation Plans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers urgently) I'm not prepared!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers back) As a Boy Scout...and you are one, aren't you, very much a Boy Scout...you must always be prepared. Nice and loud, so everyone can hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie looks at the pages, his throat constricts, his che tightens and his hands begin to shake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
