dialogues.text: I...I...I thu-thu-think we should tuh-tuh- table the document.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He attempts to return it to David, but his brother won't TKS/Seidler/09/17/08

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell the others how Mrs Simpson is to be accommodated in a special alcove above the altar. Now I'll be off. See you at Balmoral this weekend, Buh-buh-Bertie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the room, they are appalled. Bertie stands frozen and shattered.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. AUSTIN PRINCESS ON SOUTH KENSINGTON STREET
dialogues.text: The lion rampant flutters on the bonnet of the Austin. In Bertie, wearing a black armband, gestures for the driver stop. Pulling his homburg over his brow, Bertie wraps his around the lower portion of his face. Then catches his reflection in the rearview mirror. Tells his driver:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait down the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not wanting to draw attention to his destination, Bertie disembarked several buildings away from Logue's address. makes his way hurriedly. WACK. A soccer football hits him on the back.    He wheel around. The group of local lads look at him unabashed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kick it `ere, aye, Guv?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie kicks it.   A fine high shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They go back to their game. Bertie rings Logue's bell. A brief pause. Bertie glances nervously, hoping not to be recognized. Lionel opens the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To be honest, wasn't sure whether to expect you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't sure either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   55

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie stares at his mentor. Nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as they enter, referring to his hat and scarf) Do I look like a spy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a toothache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They disappear inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie has to pick his way through discarded toys and spo equipment, explaining to Logue:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was totally unable to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seldom stutter with me anymore. (referring to the mess) The boys are a bit untidy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you're paid to listen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a verbal geisha girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie looks around the cluttered, but pleasant room: comfortable furniture a bit battered by the boys, antimac to hide the wear spots on the arms, family photos everywh well-used Turkish rug on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What more does a man need,eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel stares, unsure if he's being patronized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coming from a man who's lived all his life in castles and palaces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                  56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody has to live in them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody does. Ushers Bertie into his study.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie stands shattered, lost in his painful memory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't say anything!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could've refused. Don't you know any rude words?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a bloody stupid question! I just said one. Bloody. Bloodybloodybloody!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps a touch more vulgar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To prove you know how.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bugger!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A public school prig could do better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well bloody bugger to you, you beastly bastard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hardly robust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit then. Shit, shit, shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See how defecation flows trippingly from the tongue? You don't stutter when you swear. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                 57. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I'm angry! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get angry more often. Do you know the f- word? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fornication? LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Bertie... BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck. Fuck, fuck, fuck! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bravissimo! Now a resounding chorus of... BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloody, bloody. bloody! Shit, shit, shit! Bugger, bugger, bugger! Fuck, fuck, fuck! A pounding on the wall. MYRTLE (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have children...! BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) This is your fault! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, pet! Won't happen again! MYRTLE (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should hope not! BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apologies, Mrs. Logue. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First time I've heard you laugh. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Royals aren't allowed emotions in public. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which explains a lot. Bertie is in no mood to be provoked. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                    5 BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do, dammit!? Stage my next public appearance as an obscene operetta?! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your next public appearance should be very well rehearsed. Without thinking, Lionel instinctively reaches out to pat supportively on the shoulder. Bertie pulls back in offended shock.   All the warning si instilled in him are going off. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't take liberties! You're a dangerous man, Logue. Who sent you? LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone in mind? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lurking shadows. Courtiers and peers...the whole panoply of a class which once ruled the nation which once ruled the world, afraid of losing their last vestige of privilege if the monarchy is further debased. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your wife was the one who sought me out. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because, dear sweet deluded woman, she believes in me! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you don't share her belief? Why come here? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm beginning to ask myself that very same question. Your sailing close to the edge, don't push me, Doctor Logue. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came here because I was taught from childhood to serve a purpose, and that purpose is to serve. Duty is our sole justification for privilege. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   59 BERTIE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came here because I was under the illusion you might help me perform that function! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not to worry. They say the King can do no wrong. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can bugger things up! And I am not the King. Mrs. Simpson is seeking a divorce. The Coronation is set for the 12th of May. Her decree becomes final on the 27th of April. That gives them two weeks to marry and put this issue to rest. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if Mr Baldwin stops them? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be a tragedy. I pray to The Almighty they succeed. I'll do anything within my power to keep my brother on the throne. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does that include debasing yourself? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If necessary! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your brother knew perfectly well by giving you a document without warning... BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you saying he wanted me to fail? LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you insisting he didn't? In the future we can parse any document into manageable phrases. You can sing them, swear them, rehearse them til you get the rhythm and flow; that, combined with your growing confidence... Bertie doesn't want to hear. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Growing confidence? Growing dread!!! You're a wicked man, Lionel Logue, trying to get me to thrust myself forward as an alternative to my brother. Trying to get me to commit treason! TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                    6

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trying to get you to   realize you need not be governed by fear.   Again, why did you seek me out? To take   polite elocution lessons so you could   attend posh tea parties?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How dare you! I'm the brother of a King...the son of a King...back through untold centuries. You presume to instruct me on my duty? A jumped-up jackeroo from the outback? The disappointing son of an embittered clerk! You're a monster, Doctor Logue. I'm going to Balmoral to spend a pleasant country weekend with my beloved brother. And these sessions are over!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Closed curtains. Someone fumbles behind it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel pushes his way through the gap in the curtain. A PROVINCIAL DIRECTOR replies from a seat in the auditorium the same Director as in the earlier audition scene.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you told? We aren't for London. Playing the provinces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outer Mongolia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Available, are we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing prevents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe that's called "desperate for a part!" Previous experience?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Australia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have played the provinces. Righto! Let's hear what you can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caliban?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make him deformed. Audiences like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. (rallies himself) "Be not afeard; the isle is full of noises, Sounds and sweet airs, that give delight, and hurt not."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As magical as Lionel was when he performed for his boys, he's stiff and painfully stilted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Sometimes a thousand twanging instruments Will hum about mine ears; and sometimes voices..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupts) Thank you! Don't abandon your day job. Next!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Logue bows his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel enters and sits dejectedly at the table.     Myrtl boys eat in silence. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't finished yet, Dad. (realizes) Oh! Right!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Dad. Thanks, Mum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They exit.   Myrtle knows something has happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel takes five slim folders out of his jacket pocket a them on the table in front of Myrtle. She studies them, s TKS/Seidler/09/17/08

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tickets? Home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long pause as Myrtle digests this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about your...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie's a problem...not much progress. The others have been referred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'll you do when we get home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try not to act the toff. Teach perhaps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! I'm not good enough!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gave it a try, Lionel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I had a go. Thanks to your patience. (grief overwhelms him) I just bloody well wasn't good enough!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (studying the tickets) Oh Lionel! This must've cost you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHOP!   CHOP!    CHOP! The sound of an axe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woodsman's axe CHOPS into the thick trunk of a massive Nearby, a bulldozer cuts into the green turf and rich soi The felling and earth removal are being watched by Church Lang from a distant terrace. In the background a jazz ban white tuxedos syncopates pertly. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                    6

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five hundred year old oaks! Part of the hill! Removed to improve the view!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How ever does she do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the ballroom, seem through open French doors, an afternoon dance is being held. Churchill and Lang look in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the epicenter, a dashing couple: David, the very pictu insouciance, and clinging to his arm, dripping in jewelry rather small, angular, dark haired woman, with a high bro square jaw - MRS WALLIS SIMPSON. Her most attractive phys feature is her back, displayed fully by a dress that plun her nates. Surrounded by their entourage, they are the ap chic. Watching from the sidelines:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erotic sexual techniques beyond polite imagination? I realize of course, that may be outside your personal experience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winston exchanges his empty champagne flute for a full on the tray of a passing footman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've the Devil in you today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If anyone should know, it would be Your Grace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All aspects of mankind are within my venue. Did you know, HM has trouble with his glands?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Churchill almost chokes on his champagne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd not appreciated Your Grace was so well versed concerning things testicular!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were severely damaged by the measles when HM and his brother were naval cadets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                    6

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A veritable encyclopedic font of scatological information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apparently it affects the quality, although not the quantity, of HM's endeavors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the brother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unscathed. Two daughters. I shepherd my flock in all matters, Winston, including multiplication.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They make their way inside. In the distance an Austin Pri can be seen making its way up the stately tree-line avenu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie and Elizabeth are dressed for the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must try to be pleasant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father not dead six months, and That Woman throws, "A garden potty." P-o-t-t-y. She's sleeping in your mother's bedroom. And I know perfectly well she calls me `the Dowdy Duchess", and "Cookie".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the buffet table Churchill helps himself copiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has it occurred to you, as it has only occurred to me, that a Monarch with a gland problem, who realizes he cannot produce issue, might not wish to be King...? knowing his lack of issue may well become a major issue indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dazzling concept...beautifully phrased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FOOTMAN announces: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                    6

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their Royal Highnesses the Duke and Duchess of York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallis sweeps forward to greet them, but Elizabeth sails announcing to no one in particular:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came at the invitation of the King.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David turns and bows formally. Elizabeth cursties in retu Wallis quickly returns to David, taking him forcefully on dance floor. The Yorks go in the other direction. To the side, Churchill and Lang watch David and Wallis do brisk Turkey Trot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: According to the F.B.I.... she is, after all, one of their citizens...our Monarch does not possess exclusive rights to Mrs. Simpson's sexual favours. Hitler's Ambassador, Count von Ribbentrop, has been sending her 17 carnations every day...one for each time they've slept together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good Lord, Winston, we must see to it this Empress of the Night does not become Queen of England!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vividly put.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Churchill has spotted Elizabeth in a side room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allow me to test new waters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Churchill makes his way to Elizabeth, who is standing in of a portrait of George IV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need to be told I behaved badly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the contrary, Mam. Court etiquette decrees royalty must be greeted by the official host. In this case: the King. You behaved impeccably. As always.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   66 WINSTON CHURCHILL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (referring to the painting) A relative?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Distant. WINSTON CHURCHILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (referring again to the painting) You're well aware, of course, George IV's wife, Mrs. Fitzherbert, was very common indeed...and previously married. She signed an agreement that she could never become Queen, and their children could not be Royal. A rather sensible morganatic arrangement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was   a very long time ago. You're stirring   with a rather large spoon, Winston.   Keep in mind, I'm also a distant relative   of Lady Macbeth. WINSTON CHURCHILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would disremember at my peril. David is coming briskly down the corridor, struggling to champagne bottle, followed by Bertie determined to catch Elizabeth and Churchill leave the brothers alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David... DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wally wants more champagne. I have to fetch it. She prefers that. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Been trying to see you... DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Been terribly busy. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doing what? DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Being King. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   67 BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you get that American accent? David...Father's not dead six months, yet you've put Mrs. Simpson in the suite used by our mother? DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama's not still in bed, is she? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That isn't funny. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ssssssorry, d-d-dear b-b-oy! BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. No more of that. A moment of silent confrontation. David backs down. Sort DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't realize you cared. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This could end in disaster. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This will end splendidly. With Wallis as my wife. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever will she call herself? DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Queen of England, I suspect. Kings do marry. Empress of India. The whole bag of tricks. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David! The upper classes are terrified anything which clouds the monarchy makes their situation more dangerous. Hunger marchers are singing the "Red Flag" in front of Westminster...demanding a republic...I've seen them... DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herr Hitler will sort that out. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who'll sort out Chancellor Hitler? TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   68 DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's much maligned. By the Jews, according to Wallis. And she's very clever about politics. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man's a monster! Our position must remain clear. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why's that, old chap? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are a German family! DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't bother anyone during WWI. And Kaiser Willie was our uncle. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because we took an English name! Windsor. Because we are England. We are the heart and soul of this nation. That must never change. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you already in charge? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to warn you. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I being threatened? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, your role is to consult and to be advised. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like you've studied our wretched constitution. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like you haven't. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't be a lackey to an unwashed politician like Stanley Baldwin! BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's your Prime Minister. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm his King! TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   69 BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you refuse to listen to our Government, they have no choice but to resign. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll form another. There's Winston. He'd love to be P.M. We'll create a King's Party. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To fight a general election in which your marriage is the only topic? DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd risk anything and everything for Wallis. Don't I have rights? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Privileges. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not the same thing. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yet an ordinary man may marry for love. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not ordinary men, David! We were bred to be profiles on a coin. If you were ordinary, on what basis could you possibly claim to be King?! DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the point then? Just to look posh? You know...your speech is much improved tonight. Hardly a hesitation. Yearning for a larger audience, are we? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't say such a thing! DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is my young brother trying to push me off the throne? Sounds positively medieval. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg of you, don't do this to my wife, my daughters, to me. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The politicians will give in. See you at my Coronation...Bertie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The champagne cork finally POPS. He strides off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing shot of the Prime Minister's residence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice of you to invite me to your digs, Stanley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baldwin and Churchill are alone together.    No love lost these two men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you may have guessed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Churchill is silent.   Balwin waits, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I intend to resign. The Royal scandal has weakened my position considerably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Churchill, on the edge of his seat, can't suppress an anticipatory grin. Baldwin takes pleasure in deflating it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No need to volunteer your services, Winston. Neville Chamberlain will take my place, once this Royal matter is settled. As Chancellor of the Exchequer he already lives next door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My opportunity to redecorate will come soon enough, Stanley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will it? Well, enough chit-chat. The question of a morganatic marriage, as a possible solution, has been put to the Dominion Prime Ministers. After all, HM is their King too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baldwin has a sheath of telegrams in hand. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                    7

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Australia: no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David feels there aren't that many people in Australia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Canada: no. Union of South Africa: an inappropriate marriage would create a permanent wound. The Irish Free State: states it is not really their affair, and, bluntly, our English King may marry any whore he wants, they'll be well out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloody Irish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New Zealand...wavers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, the Kiwis!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Being rather remote, they've not even heard of Mrs Simpson. Hardly a winning hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not about true love, Winston. This is about who's in charge. Does the King do what he wants, or what his people want him to do? Does the King own his nation, or does the nation own their Monarch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't budge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nor will we.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winston Churchill is incongruously inspecting a rocking h Unable to resist, he sits on it gingerly, rocking back an lost in a reverie. Eyes closed he extends his right arm a though holding a cavalry saber. Bertie enters startling h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't dismount.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   72 WINSTON CHURCHILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good of you to see me at this late hour. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought you were in David's camp? WINSTON CHURCHILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was. (takes a piece of paper from his pocket and reads) "I am now free to tell you how I was jockeyed out of the Throne." BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good Lord! My brother wrote that? WINSTON CHURCHILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallis wrote it for him. I'll burn it. I fear your brother is like the child in a fairy story, given everything in the world, but they forgot his soul. Quite happy to bring his nation to the brink of civil war just as we face global conflict. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not coming to that?! WINSTON CHURCHILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, there'll be war, alright. (takes out another piece of paper) Your brother held conversations with the Duke of Saxe-Coburg, your cousin, a ranking member of the Nazi party. I have the Scotland Yard intercept: "Who is King here? Baldwin or I? I myself wish to talk with Hitler, and will do so here or in Germany." I doubt England is ready to return to absolute monarchy. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surely his motives are misunderstood? WINSTON CHURCHILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "If I don't get my way, when the war comes, Hitler will crush everyone, including the Americans. The British may not want me as their King, but I'll soon be back as their leader." His intent seems crystal clear. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winston?! Don't take him seriously! TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                    7

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mugs for his cancelled Coronation will soon be on clearance sale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're willing to go along with this?! Changing horses in mid-stream is a perilous maneuver!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Depends how badly the horse you're on stumbles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not too late, Winston, you could form a government on his behalf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must decline. Reluctantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rocking horse CRACKS.   Churchill gets to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. (starts to exit, then) I've written a new speech for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to hear it! Ever!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It does have a rather nice turn of phrase.

dialogues.speaker: BRITISH STREETS
dialogues.text: It is December 11th, 1936. If practical use the actual re broadcast (truncated). In London, Birmingham, Edinburgh, country hamlets and cathedral towns...the streets are des Stragglers hurry indoors to be near:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At long last I am able to say a few words of my own. Until now it has not been constitutionally possible for me to speak. A few hours ago I discharged my last duty as King and Emperor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie and Elizabeth listening to the radio with the two princesses royal sitting at their parents' feet. Bertie b his emotions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that I have been succeeded by my brother, the Duke of York, my first words must be to declare my allegiance to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) Daddy, who broke our rocking horse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) A giant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth holds a finger to her lips: shush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This has been made less difficult to me by the sure knowledge that my brother has one matchless blessing, enjoyed by so many of you, and not bestowed on me -- a happy home with his wife and children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The glow of a radio dial. Lionel and Myrtle sit in armcha the radio on a side-table between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have found it impossible to carry the heavy burden of responsibility and to discharge my duties as King as I would wish to do without the help and support of the woman I love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel gets up to turn it off as David's voice concludes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all have a new King. I wish him and you, his people, happiness and prosperity with all my heart. God bless you all! God save the King!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Logue strokes Myrtle's hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I too "married the woman I love."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   75 MYRTLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You married a shop girl. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wonderful lass. Someone I can talk to heart to heart. MYRTLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Using simple words and short sentences. I'm very ordinary. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why we're suited. I'm just an ordinary bloke. MYRTLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordinary? You're a man with wild dreams, Lionel. Mine are so very small. A job, a husband, a home. Raising our sons. That's all I ever wanted. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too. MYRTLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that why, every day, you've spent hours with a man who's about to be King? LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That relationship is now past tense. MYRTLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yet, for as long as you could, you did what you wanted. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to be a great actor. That's what I wanted. MYRTLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And failing that... LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I certainly failed! MYRTLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A great healer. Always...'great'. Where does a shop girl fit in? LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very snugly, into my heart! Always have, always will. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   76

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trouble is, Lionel, when you say that, I still believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Royal standard on a gleaming car's bonnet. Bertie stands uneasily in the uniform of an Admiral of th as the driver opens the door. Bertie realizes its a Rolls

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the Austin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Palace changed it, Your Highness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I liked the Austin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So did I, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two girls wave from their open playroom window, and c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look like a chicken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rooster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waves, and gets in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A formal voice announces:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His Majesty will address the Accession Council and take his oath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie looks at himself in a full length mirror, making l minute adjustments to his uniform. Staring at his reflect

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did this happen to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie walks to the podium like a man to the gallows face an array of the Privy Councillors, members of the House o Lords, the Lord Mayor of the City of London, the Aldermen City of London and the High Commissioners of the Commonwe countries. All the old symptoms reappear: the tightening of the neck muscles, the protruding Adam's apple, the jaw locking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Lords, members of the Accession Council, I meet you today in circumstances which are without parallel in the history of our Country...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Its going to be a terrible performance. He bows his head humility. And shame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth is playing quietly with her daughters when the opens and Bertie appears, still in full regalia, straight the Accession Council. He holds his arm out, expecting th run to him for a hug and kiss, his solace after the ordea They remain where they are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy's home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They curtsy formally. LILIBET & MARGARET ROSE Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie is devastated.   Elizabeth takes him quickly out i corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to lose you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could you possibly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Being what we both dread most.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear, dear, man, I refused your first two marriage proposals because, as much as I loved you, I couldn't abide the thought of living in the Royal gilded cage. Then I realized...you stuttered so beautifully...they'd leave you alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes his face in her hands tenderly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I must be Queen, I will be a good Queen. The wife of a very great King indeed. (then) You know what you must do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 73   INT.   LOGUE'S CONSULTATION ROOM & WAITING ROOM Logue is working with Anna. She's reading smoothly and wi great intensity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Had I the heavens' embroidered cloths Enwrought with golden and silver light, The bbb..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gets stuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We haven't much more time together. Give it a go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doorbell RINGS.     Logue is annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There weren't any more appointments today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bell RINGS again.    He yells:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Piss off! (gently) Anna?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The blue and the dim and the dark cloths Of night and light and the half-light..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and Bertie enters the waiting area. Hearin he stops outside the consultation room and listens. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   79 ANNA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I would spread the cloths under your feet, But I, being poor, have only my dreams. I have spread my dreams under your feet; Tread softly because you tread on my dreams." Silence. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Read it to him. If he doesn't profess his love, he's not a man. Anna nods earnestly. ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you...Lionel. She exits via the Waiting Room and almost runs into Berti recognizing him, she bobs her head. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was lovely. Don't take any guff. ANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I tell my Harold that's what you said? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be honoured. She dashes off. Logue comes to the door of the Waiting Room, in effect bl Bertie's way in. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnson, isn't it? Have you an appointment? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want me to beg? LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you, Kings don't beg. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe this time a bit of begging might be required. Elizabeth says I must eat humble crow. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Its "crow" or "humble pie". Take your pick. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   80

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gathering resolve)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was frightened and took refuge in being `Royal'. What I said was unforgivable. And...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blurts out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the one essential thing a King must do? He must believe he is King. How can I possibly do that? For pity sake, Lionel, I beg you: get me through! I'll pay you another shilling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're friends for? Logue steps aside, letting Bertie in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The double bed is piled high with clothing, a suitcase at foot. Myrtle is sorting. She hears Lionel enter behind he first, she doesn't turn. Lionel remains silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got the boys sorting their things. Your office will be a chore... Realizing something is amiss, she turns, and knows instan what Lionel's going to tell her. Her hand goes to her mou stifle her emotions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie is with visitors: Churchill and Lang. There's a sl but discernible change in his demeanor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We asked to see Your Highness because there's the urgent question of what to call your brother. Aside from the obvious. Bertie is not pleased with His Grace's joke, but lets it TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   81 BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you suggest? COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Edward Windsor? All he deserves. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What has my brother given up on his abdication, other than the throne? They look at each other, unsure. BERTIE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't it be a good idea to find out before coming to me? He cannot be Mister, as he was born the son of a Duke. Which makes him a Lord at the very least. WINSTON CHURCHILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well, Lord E.W. it is. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as a Lord of the realm, he's entitled to be elected to the House of Commons. Heading a King's Party. COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unacceptable! BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you prefer he takes a seat in the House of Lords? Again, on behalf of a King's Party? Is that acceptable? WINSTON CHURCHILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly not. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if he's made a Royal Duke, and called His Royal Highness, he cannot stand for Parliament. Nor may he speak or vote in the House of Lords. COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (realizing) Oh I say... BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Duke of Windsor it is. Gentlemen. He exits abruptly. Churchill and Lang gather their things stunned. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                    8

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not exactly a dummy, is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myrtle is in the shop window, arranging handbags, luggage briefcases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the store Myrtle can be seen dressing the window, whil his glass office the OWNER, a portly bald gentleman with Dickensian air, is deep in concerned conversation with a trench-coat. The Owner keeps glancing worriedly in Myrtle direction. The two men nod, shake hands. The fellow in the trench-co leaves. The owner beckons another shop-girl over and whis something to her. She heads towards Myrtle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Let's go gathering hearty heather with the gay brigade of grand dragons."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wall divides the study from the living area, allowing t action in both spaces to be viewed. IN THE PARLOUR: Elizabeth waits, ill at ease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Splendid. Here's another. "She sifted seven thick-stalked thistles through strong thick sieves." At home, twenty-five times, in rapid succession.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are my hardest sounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel gives him a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we invite your wife in now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08 Logue goes to the door and starts to open it. He shuts it quickly. LIONEL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't expecting Myrtle for several hours! IN THE PARLOUR: Myrtle has entered, definitely unhappy. S Elizabeth, she's even less happy, and flabbergasted. MYRTLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milady? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Your Majesty", the first time. After that, "Ma'am". Not Malm as in Palm, Mam as in ham. I'm informed your husband calls my husband Bertie and my husband calls your husband Lionel. I trust, however, you won't attempt to call me Liz. IN THE STUDY: Lionel stands listening, ear to the door. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How're they getting on? LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As to be expected. IN THE PARLOUR: Myrtle announces: MYRTLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may call me "Madam Logue". Myrtle's at a loss knowing what to do with a Duchess. MYRTLE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I offer you a cup of tea, Ma'am? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Madame Logue, but I'm waiting to be summoned. Silence. MYRTLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't like my husband. That's what I was told. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was told the same.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE STUDY
dialogues.text: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   84 BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do we remain in hiding? LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going out there!

dialogues.speaker: IN THE PARLOUR
dialogues.text: MYRTLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you dislike about my Lionel? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't wish my husband to be demeaned. What don't you like about mine? MYRTLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want my Lionel getting hurt. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's only one thing can save him now: success. IN THE STUDY: the men are growing increasingly nervous. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're being cowards. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. We're sensible men. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should go in. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? You. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why me?! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the Royal. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Being a monarchist, I recognize these are your digs. Therefore: here you rule. Therefore: you go in. Urged by Bertie, Logue opens the door. IN THE PARLOUR: Logue enters, pretending total innocence surprise, followed by Bertie, also trying to keep the pre TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                    8 LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! Hello, Lady Elizabeth! Oh! Hello, Myrtle darling! What a pleasant surprise. Myrtle stares at him and takes her revenge. MYRTLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will the Yorks be staying for dinner? Logue and Bertie look panic-stricken.   Elizabeth comes t rescue. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A previous engagement. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some other time, love. Logue ushers Elizabeth into the study, giving Myrtle a ne little wave. She glares and exits.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE STUDY
dialogues.text: LIONEL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glad you had a chance to meet Myrtle. Bertie stifles a snort. Elizabeth glares at him. LIONEL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Elizabeth) Good of you to come. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harley Street is far too public. What is my function here? LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For me to show you how to pitch in. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh dear, I may not be a `pitch in' type. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Piece of cake. (to Bertie) Please assume a supine position on the floor. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Firm support is needed. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08 Bertie dutifully lies on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breathe deeply...expand your chest... now your stomach...deep into the diaphragm. Splendid. How do you feel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full of hot air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well on your way to becoming a qualified political speaker. Again... Bertie inhales deeply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and hold. Now, Princess Elizabeth, be so kind as to sit on your husband's stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good grief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gently of course. Elizabeth sits gingerly on Bertie's stomach, asking solicitously:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you alright, Bertie? Bertie nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now exhale slowly...down goes Princess Elizabeth...inhale slowly...nothing rushed, expanding your chest fully, extending the column of air til it hits the diaphragm...and...up comes Princess Elizabeth. Exhale...down goes Princess Elizabeth...inhale...up comes Princess Elizabeth. You get the idea. Doesn't have to be Princess Elizabeth of course, but I thought you'd prefer your wife to one of the staff. Now comes the fun part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's actually more? Bertie springs to his feet while Logue opens a window. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will now shout the vowel sounds, all five of them, as loudly as possible, each to last no less than 15 seconds. There's poor coordination between your larynx and diaphragm. Princess Elizabeth, you can be the official timer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vowel sounds? Shouted at an open window? On a public street?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone who can stand at an open window vibrating loudly in full view of the world can learn to give a public speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can also be considered quite dotty. Don't even contemplate it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, dear, doctor's orders. Aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa... (stops) She's right, those two chaps are staring at me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're always looking at you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (startled) You're followed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Royal scrutiny, Doctor, best get used to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaayyyyyyyyyyy... ...eeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeee... (to Elizabeth) Are you timing this? iiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiii... ooooooooooooooooooooooooo... uuuuuuuuuuu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family eat in tense silence TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                  88. VALENTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May we be excused?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. The unhappy meal continues. PETER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mumbles) We don't want to hear you fight. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not fighting. Your mother isn't talking. MYRTLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wish me to speak my mind? LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boys, leave. THE BOYS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Dad! Thank you, Mum! They exit hurriedly. MYRTLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel...without warning, I arrive home to find the Queen in my parlour. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Duchess, she hasn't been crowned yet. MYRTLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel, don't quibble! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you think of her? MYRTLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it matter!? She's the Queen and he's the King forgodsake! What're they doing here?! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why'd you come home so early?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel... LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They came for help. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What role are you auditioning for now? Royal saviour?! Who's going to help us?! This will bring us down, Lionel. You know it will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When that poor chap first walked into my office, he was a slim, quiet man with tired eyes and all the outward symptoms of the person upon whom a habitual speech defect has set the sign. You saw him today; once more there was hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not listening to me! She gets up angrily and starts carrying dishes to the kit He follows her back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myrtle, I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You say that, but you don't listen when I say, in so many ways, how desperately I want to go home, how I never, ever, intended to stay here. This was to be a holiday trip to see `Mother England', and you turned it into quite something else. What happened, Lionel? We went to Wembley Stadium, next thing...you'd cashed in our tickets. He's silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well, I shan't talk of this ever again. I will, as always, be supportive of your endeavours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myrtle... I don't deserve a wonderful woman like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How right you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why'd you come home so early?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel...I was let go. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   90 He's stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inquiries were made...Mr Falkoff wouldn't say who...afterwards it was: `With your hubby treating a personage that high and mighty, you won't be needing employment with us, will you, Mrs Logue?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (anguished) Why?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're frightened, Lionel. Of what seems so far above them. I sympathize. I'm frightened too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Myrtle. My love...

dialogues.speaker: WESTMINSTER ABBEY
dialogues.text: Establishing shot of this architectural icon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winston, you do read the newspapers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A massive cavern of stone statuary and stained glass. The center piece of this particular section is the throne of the Confessor. Scaffolding is in the process of being ere to supply lighting for the Coronation. Archbishop Lang an Churchill inspect it with satisfaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only the vulgar ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Churchill pours two nips of whiskey into metal cups neste hip flask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To our new King.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's sincerely hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at each other in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this a `slightly pregnant pause'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   91 COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say he is dim. WINSTON CHURCHILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Demonstrably untrue. COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say he has epilepsy. WINSTON CHURCHILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patently erroneous. COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fragile, prone to illness... WINSTON CHURCHILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some correctness in that. COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and will die prematurely. They predict he'll be unable to complete the Coronation. WINSTON CHURCHILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you propose? Shorten the ceremony? Or no ceremony at all? COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My idea exactly! WINSTON CHURCHILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believed so. But what we need is a pageant of pomp and pomposity to impress the world. COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What we need, and what we'll get, may be two rather different things. Did you hear his pathetic attempt at the Accession Council? He'll never be able to speak in public. WINSTON CHURCHILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, we plonk a tinsel crown on his head and lock him in a closet? Who then will spiritually lead this great nation into war? Who will address the far flung corners of the Empire, rallying all to our defense? COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... WINSTON CHURCHILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Head of our Church? Is that what you have in mind? TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   92 COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would it be such a calamity? WINSTON CHURCHILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best ask our new King. Bertie has entered with Logue. Lang spins around. COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Majesty. WINSTON CHURCHILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir, duty calls. He exits quickly. Cosmo continues nervously as they walk through the Abbey, the Archbishop pointing out the prepar in progress, particularly a booth for broadcasters. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this the scene of the crime? COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a peculiar thing to say. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Referring to my assault upon the ears of the listeners. COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, yes, wireless is indeed a Pandora's Box. I have, however, categorically said no to the BBC's new "radio-with-pictures" gadget. Imagine, the unwashed viewing us as we blow our noses or scratch our bottoms. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Radio with pictures?! COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is called..."television". Happily, with a transmission range of only fifteen miles this "TV" thing has no future. We shall, however, be forced to permit cinema; the product of which I shall personally edit. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'll keep you busy, removing all my stops and starts. COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless of course you'd prefer a quiet ceremony? TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   93 BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What exactly do you mean? COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something...discreet...private. We could pre-record an edited version to be broadcast to the world. Or even find an actor with a similar voice. Logue has arrived and comes out of the shadows. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A King based upon deception? Cosmo takes Bertie aside. COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If your gentleman from Security would give us space, we could discuss this in private. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean my bodyguard,"Crusher?" Giving Lionel a scathing look, Lang continues speaking to confidentially. COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fret not. As I assured our nation in my recent broadcast: "When his people listen to their new Monarch they will note an occasional momentary hesitation in his speech. But to those who hear it, it need cause no sort of embarrassment, for it causes none to him who speaks." You see, I've paved the way. But should you wish to avoid further stress... LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not paint him pink and cover him with sequins? COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon?! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you wish to call attention to his anxiety. COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does your bodyguard know to whom he's speaking? He certainly doesn't know his place! TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   94 BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor Lionel Logue, my speech therapist. COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Therapist?! I'd no idea! Had I known Your Majesty was seeking assistance I would've made my own recommendation. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Logue is to be present at the Coronation. COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impossibly to find room. Even for a Doctor. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just Lionel. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind the chair of Edward the Confessor. COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Royal Box!? Your Family will be seated there. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which makes it most suitable. COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps I might be able to add a very small stool. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two comfortable chairs. One for Madam Logue. She's a close friend of my wife. The Queen. COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have someone attend to it. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now, if you don't mind, we need the premises. COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear fellow, this is Westminster Abbey! The Church must make preparations. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So must Bertie. COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie?! We do not call the King: "Bertie"! TKS/Seidler/09/17/08 LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do. During waking hours we'll need the facilities. It'll be a closed set. No observers. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are my wishes, Your Grace. Lang nods curtly and exits. BERTIE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've made a dangerous enemy. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't want him as a friend. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And don't ever call me Bertie in public. A moment of confrontation.    Lionel knows he's overstepp

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me... BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sense one of your dreadful questions on the horizon. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you really want to be King? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knew it! I haven't any choice. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can be a wounded King who stumbles through his Coronation. Or, as the Arch of C so archly suggests, no Coronation at all. Always a choice. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this, you wait til Westminster Abbey, then ambush me? LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm simply asking questions... which you seem unable to answer. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a sacrificial lamb being led to slaughter! Damn you! TKS/Seidler/09/17/08 LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite possibly. But at least I know what I want. You haven't the foggiest. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (explodes)

dialogues.speaker: I WANT TO BE HEARD
dialogues.text: His words reverberate through the empty abbey. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's quite different. Let's get down to work then, shall we? Bertie glares at him. LIONEL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As soon as you and Elizabeth enter the West door, you'll be greeted with the hymn "I Was Glad When They Said Unto Me." You won't actually be that glad, because they sing it for a great long time. Bertie follows Logue deep into the bowels of the `Abbey'. LIONEL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll then show yourself to the various sides of the Abbey as the Archbishop announces four times in a loud voice, "Sirs, I here present unto you..." Have you decided your name for when you become King? For when you become a different person?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like your father? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like my father. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not Albert? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Given the current situation...too Germanic. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Sirs, I here present unto you, GEORGE, your undoubted King!" TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   97 "George, your undoubted King!" echoes through the Abby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lang is on the phone. The door is open. While talking he watches the work preparations. On the phone he tells some

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've made inquiries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Logue enters and sits at the table. Myrtle serves him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bit dry. Tried to keep it warm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm... Kedgeree! Lovely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look done in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've news for you. You're coming to the Coronation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've news for you. I'm not!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand in the rain hoping for a glimpse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Royal Box. You and I. Stunned silence, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel...I'd need a new dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rather thought you might. Valentine calls from the next room: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad! Phone! For you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't be a sec.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He exits. Myrtle waits. Looks at herself, bemused, reflec a glass-fronted cabinet. Even does a curtsey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last of the preparation crew are being scurried out b He gives a final, satisfied, look at the cavernous space, director preparing the stage for a final scene. He quotes Shakespeare, extremely pleased with himself:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The play's the thing, wherein I'll catch the conscience of a King."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He exits. THE CAMERA explores various elements: The Throne of Edward the Confessor. Beneath it, a large rough-hewn stone: The Stone Of Scone. Leaning against the Throne, a huge sword, set there for t Coronation rehearsal. Majestic stained glass windows of saints, kings, and mart Rows of pews, worn with centuries of use. Graves of the mighty: kings, poets, and statesmen. This Abbey holds the history of a nation. Footsteps resonate. Lionel enters.   Trips over one of the gravestones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie? Blast! Stepped on Lord Byron. Bertie...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lights snap on skewering Lionel. Bertie steps into view w a coat against the night chill of the stone cathedral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not a rehearsal, "Doctor" Logue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   99 LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, the Star Chamber inquisition. I wondered when that would happen. And I'd promised Myrtle a new frock. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barely controlled) "Just call me Lionel"! Never did you call yourself `Doctor'. We did that for you. No diploma, no training, no credentials. Just a great deal of nerve. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to hear my side of the story? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There isn't a "your-side-of-the-story". This is my story. And you've ruined it! Its not just the Coronation, terrifying enough, its the radio speech to millions afterwards, and the speech after that, and for the rest of my failed miserable life! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Wembley Stadium... BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You dare remind me?! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was there. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you knew from the start I was hopeless?! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My son, Valentine, asked, "Could you help that poor man?" I replied, "He's too old for me to manage a complete cure, but I could very nearly do it, I'm sure of that." BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lying bastard! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew I could help you. You refuse to believe? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In you?! TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                    1 LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In yourself. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the hell do you think you are?! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A failed actor. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actor? LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father wanted me to be a doctor, but I couldn't cut flesh. So I worked in the mines, recited in pubs... BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An actor?! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the war came, by the time I was ready to be shipped out, the first casualties were limping home. Poor buggers, broken in bone and spirit. `Lionel, you're good with your mouth, see if you can help these poor sods.' The shell-shocked were the saddest. Most stuttered profoundly. Far worse than you. Muscle therapy helped somewhat, but I found I had to go deeper, as you might well imagine. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know nothing of those poor men! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you do. They had cried out, and the universe had not listened. So they'd lost faith in their voice. My job was to make them shout in righteous anger: "I have the right to be heard!" BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose that helped them, did it? LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make inquiries. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inquiries have been made! No credentials. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But a lot of success. No training was given. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                    1 LIONEL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not in Western Australia, not at that time. I simply knew what to do. When the war was over I kept being a therapist to earn a living. When the lads were old enough, I thought, "Alright Lionel, you've always wanted to be an actor, one last go." I pretended it was our trip home to Mother England, the Great Australian Pilgrimage. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To Harley Street?! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cashed in our return tickets. I had three months rent. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you set yourself up on Harley Street as an actor? Harley Street, don't you know, is for doctors! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plaque says, `L. Logue. Speech Specialist'. No mention of a medical degree. No mention of any degree. Some of the diggers I'd helped had come to England. They made referrals. My practice flourished. My acting, however, did not. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well enough to deceive me. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lock me in the Tower. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would if I could! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What crime? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've saddled this nation in its moment of peril with a voiceless King. Destroyed the happiness of my family...all for the sake of ensnaring a star client you knew you couldn't possibly assist! Lionel sits down on the chair of Edward the Confessor. Le against it is the great two-handed sword of St. George. BERTIE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you doing? Get up! TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                    1 LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm tired. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't sit there! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? It's a chair. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the Chair of Edward The Confessor! The throne upon which every King for six and a half centuries has been crowned. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's falling apart. People have carved their initials into it. Needs a stone to keep from blowing away. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the Stone of Scone! The Stone of Destiny that was once Jacob's pillow. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You believe such ballocks I don't care how many royal backsides have sat on it, it's a building block with handles attached. You're just like me, an actor with tawdry stage props you choose to believe are real. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me... ! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to you?! By what right? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Divine right, if you must! I'm your King!!! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noooo you're not! Told me so yourself. Said you didn't want it. So why should I listen to a poor stuttering bloke who can't put one word after another? Why waste my time listening to you? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I have a right to be heard! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heard as what?! BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man! I HAVE A VOICE!!! TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                    1 LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Well then...you're cured. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop trying to squirm off the hook. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie, you'll make a bloody good king. And you know it. Bertie stares at him. A familiar voice is heard from the shadows. VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Majesty? The Archbishop of Canterbury. COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be relieved to learn I've found a replacement specialist. Impeccable credentials. There's a long silence. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That won't be necessary. COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The matter's already been settled. For your own well-being. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you say? COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Majesty's function is to consult...and to be advised. You didn't consult, but you've just been advised. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I advise you, so listen carefully. ...in this personal matter I will make my own decision. COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I remind you, you do not place the crown upon your own head. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And may I remind you, it is my head upon which the crown is placed! TKS/Seidler/09/17/08

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This will end badly. Lang turns on his heel. Lionel ignores what has just happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In hushed tones the BBC commentator paints a picture for the world, as you stand at the altar divested of your robes. Trumpets echo through the Abbey. The incessant rain clears miraculously as a shaft of sun streams through the stained-glass window catching your golden tunic and bathing you in light like a mediaeval knight. And you are King! The faint CLICKING WHIR of a film projector is heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the screen: archive footage of the Coronation, capturi pomp and ceremony. Cigar smoke rises up. The voices of Churchill and Lang can be heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was much moved

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There were tears in my eyes too, Your Grace, particularly when I saw you and the Dean of Westminster cannoning into each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's been edited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More tears when our new Monarch started towards his throne, only to be brought to an abrupt halt owing to one of the Bishops treading on his robe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the world, all went splendidly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amidst a vitrine of glittering jewels, bobbing tiaras, and heaving bosoms. The footage freezes momentarily. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Winston, I have something which will bring tears to your eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The archive footage continues, but it is not of the Coron David and Wallis visiting the Fuhrer in Germany: Hitler gallantly kissing Mrs Simpson's hand while Goring and the of Windsor beam; David giving the Nazi salute. FREEZE FRA The lights come on. For once, Churchill is speechless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no doubt: David is planning a comeback. And will succeed if our King continues to falter.
