Though Bertie miraculously survived the Coronation he continues to stumble very badly indeed. Soon he must broadcast to the world. Hitler will be listening. David will be listening. Stalin and Roosevelt will be listening. Everyone will be listening. God help us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stuttering very badly) "In this grave hour... "

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie and Logue are rehearsing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "In this grave hour... " Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "In this grave hour... "

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn the halts into pauses, during which you say to yourself, "God save the King".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say that all the time, but apparently no one's listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Use the silence. Long pauses add solemnity to great occasions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I'm the solemnest king who ever lived. Lionel, I can't do this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                    1 Logue tries to protest, Bertie over-rides. BERTIE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I am to be King...where is my power? May I form a Government on my own, appoint or dismiss a Prime Minister, chose an Ambassador, levy a tax or declare a war? None of these things. Yet I am the seat of all authority. Why? Because the Nation believes when I speak, I speak for them. Yet I cannot speak! Logue totally ignores the outburst. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it from the top. "In this grave hour..." BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitates, then) "In this grave hour, p-p-perhaps..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on... BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The letter`P' is always difficult. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get a running start, put the words all together. `Perhaps-the-most-fateful...' BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "In this grave hour...perhaps-the-most- fateful...in our history..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beaut. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "... I send to every household of my peoples...both at home and overseas..." LIONEL (SINGS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doo-dah, doo-dah. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...this message... " LIONEL (SINGS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five miles long... TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                    1 BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...spoken with the same depth of feeling for each one of you... as if I were able..." LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In your head, now: "Bugger, bugger, bugger! Damn, damn, damn! All those bloody blighters are going to have to listen to me!" Can you dance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helps relax the body. (goes to record player) Waltz? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I prefer pipes. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought you might. (starts a bagpipe record of "Scotland The Brave") Dance with me. One, two, one-two-three- four. One, two, one- two-three-four. "For the second time..." one-two-three-four "... in the lives of most of us..." one, two, one-two-three- four "... we are at war." Three, four. Dancing at arm's length with Logue, Bertie repeats: BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "For the second time... in the lives of most of us... we are at war." One-two- three. (continues on) "Over and over again... we have tried to find a peaceful way... out of the differences... between ourselves... and those who are now our enemies." Bugger, bugger, bugger! Fuck, fuck, fuck! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be ready. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) The shilling you won... still have it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   10 Bertie holds out his hand, demandingly. Somewhat hurt, Li hands it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll return it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie leaves with the shilling, exiting the back way. Logue opens the waiting room door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie! Where's your mum?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stuttering painfully) She had to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been waiting here, alone, all this time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie nods again. Then, haltingly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard the King.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sang. And shouted rude words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie beams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to sing, dance, and shout rude words?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why am I not surprised?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dreaded BBC microphone. The room has been transformed into an ad hoc broadcasting for this all-important occasion. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                    1 The BBC News Reader and Floor Manager are there, along wi small cluster of technicians putting finishing touches to equipment. FLOOR MANAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think he'll manage? BBC NEWS READER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard he may not even show. The Floor Manager tries to warn him with his eyes. Bertie has entered with Elizabeth and Logue. The Reader w he could sink into the floor. Bertie says nothing, but approaches the looming microphone, while Logue and Elizab watch nervously. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `Walk up to the bloody thing boldly, stare it square in the eye, man to man.' BBC NEWS READER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (placating) If you'll be so kind, to let me show you... BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already know. My father taught me. He spreads the fingers of one hand, touches the apparatus the little finger, thumb to chin. The Reader scurries off and tells the others. BBC NEWS READER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His father taught him. I taught his father. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (testing the microphone) Bugger bugger bugger...bloody bloody bloody... ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie, do make sure that's not switched on! LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to be splendid. And if you're not? BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll bloody well have to listen to me anyway. Right? TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                    1 LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloody right. Lang and Churchill have entered. Elizabeth forces herself greet them graciously. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Prime Minister, Your Grace, how kind of you to join us. COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't miss this for the world. (to Churchill) Congratulations. Neville didn't last long, did he? Talking to Hitler. WINSTON CHURCHILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My tenure will be shorter, if the King fails tonight. Bertie and Logue speak privately. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No matter how this turns out, I wish to thank you. For asking such dreadful questions. What can I do in recompense? LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lighty...yet seriously) I've always wanted to be knighted. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. That would raise too many questions. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause, then) Understood. Bertie takes something from his pocket. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your shilling. Told you I'd give it back. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep it for good luck. BERTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you won this, fair and square. The object is a silver medal. Bertie pins it to Logue's j TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                    1 BERTIE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Made from the melted coin. Designed it myself, hope you like it, Lionel old friend. May I call you that? LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My greatest honour, Bertie. (then) One final question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh dear. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you believe you're King? A very long pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost. The red light on the microphone starts to blink.   Logue the others. The Reader is at a smaller microphone near the ad hoc `br booth. Five, four, three, two... BBC NEWS READER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, this is the BBC National and World programme, broadcasting from Buckingham Palace. His Majesty, the King. During this, Bertie's hands begin to shake, the pages of speech rattle like dry leaves, his throat muscles constri Adam's apple bulges, his lips tighten...all the old sympt reappear. Several seconds have elapsed since the Reader finished. seems an eternity. Elizabeth grasps the sides of her chair with white knuckl Lang's eyes roll heavenward. Churchill studies the situation, ready to leap into the b Bertie and Logue stare at each other. Logue smiles, perfectly calm, totally confident in the ma worked with. His confidence is contagious. Bertie takes a deep breath and lets it out slowly. His ha grow steady, his throat muscles relax...all the things he practiced. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The luminous dial of a wireless.   Unbearable silence. Th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In this grave hour, perhaps the most fateful in our history, I send to every household of my peoples, both at home and overseas...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is being listened to by Myrtle and the boys. The boy at their mum. Suddenly they explode with cheers as the ra address continues:

dialogues.speaker: WORLD
dialogues.text: In homes, pubs (where we see the man with the rosacea nos clubs, hotels, boarding houses, factories, mines, prisons shearing shed in New Zealand, cattle station in Australia in India, South Africa, loci around the Commonwealth and China. Japan. The Kremlin. The White House. Hitler's moun top wolf den. The South of France (where David and Wallis dolefully.) During this, the address continues, with dramatic pauses sure, but no real hesitations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...this message spoken with the same depth of feeling for each one of you as if I were able to cross your threshold and speak to you myself. For the second time in the lives of most of us we are at war. For we are called, with our allies, to meet the challenge of a principle which, if it were to prevail, would be fatal to any civilized order in the world. It is the principle which permits a State, in the selfish pursuit of power, to disregard its treaties and its solemn pledges; which sanctions the use of force, or threat of force, against the sovereignty and independence of other States. Such a principle, stripped of all disguise, is surely the mere primitive doctrine that might is right, and if this principle were established throughout the world, the freedom of our own country and of the whole British Commonwealth of Nations would be in danger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TKS/Seidler/09/17/08

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But far more than this - the peoples of the world would be kept in the bondage of fear, and all hopes of settled peace and of the security of justice and liberty among nations would be ended. This is the ultimate issue which confronts us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: End the montage with a return to the exterior of Buckingh Palace. Outside, stand solemn crowds, listening to the sp on loudspeakers. PAN THEIR FACES, the faces of England, stalwart and resolved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the sake of all that we ourselves hold dear, and of the world's order and peace, it is unthinkable that we should refuse to meet the challenge. It is to this high purpose that I now call my people at home and my peoples across the seas, who will make our cause their own. I ask them to stand calm, firm, and united in this time of trial. The task will be hard. There may be dark days ahead, and war can no longer be confined to the battlefield. But we can only do the right as we see the right, and reverently commit our cause to God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two girls listen to their father on the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If one and all we keep resolutely faithful to it, ready for whatever service or sacrifice it may demand, then, with God's help, we shall prevail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilibet's expression tells it all - she can hear it, her is truly King.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS
dialogues.text: Bertie, in his quiet way is totally in command, and utter magnificent. Everyone in the room is awed as he concludes TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   11 BERTIE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We may all find a message of encouragement in the lines which, in my closing words, I would like to say to you: `I said to the man who stood at the Gate of the Year, "Give me a light that I may tread safely into the unknown." And he replied, "Go out into the darkness, and put your hand into the Hand of God. That shall be to you better than light, and safer than a known way.'" May the Almighty Hand guide and uphold us all. IN THE AD HOC `CONTROL BOOTH' AREA - the Manager makes a gesture to Bertie, he's off the air, the red light on the microphone goes out. The Manager points, and the red ligh the Reader's microphone goes on. BBC NEWS READER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This concludes the BBC broadcast of the King's Speech. Another `cut' gesture from the Floor Manager, the red lig out and the transmission is concluded. The Floor Manager to the Reader. BBC NEWS READER (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) He wasn't perfect. (barely controlling his tears) Not perfect... But by God... He moved me. AT THE MAIN BBC MICROPHONE - Bertie waits for the verdict peers. Churchill first: WINSTON CHURCHILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't have said it better myself. The ultimate compliment.   Lang next. COSMO LANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm speechless. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Thank God. She goes to Bertie and kisses him tenderly on the cheek, his hand, then Logue's. TKS/Seidler/09/17/08                                   11 ELIZABETH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well done, Bertie. Well done... (for the first time) ...Lionel. Well done. She leaves the two men together. LIONEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always called you Bertie. Today, I call you King. He offers his hand. But instead of taking it, Bertie take by the shoulders and gives him a hug. This is a long way the five pace rule. The last barrier has fallen. Scroll:
